## Problem 1: 

(1): By definition, a probability mass function must satisify $\sum^t f(t) = 1$, if $x \in \{0, 1, 2\}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\text{then } \sum_{i = 0}^2 \frac{k}{2^x} &= 1 \\ 
\frac{k}{2^0} + \frac{k}{2^1} + \frac{k}{2^2} &= 1 \\
\frac{k}{1} + \frac{k}{2} + \frac{k}{4} &= 1 \\
\frac{4k}{4} + \frac{2k}{4} + \frac{k}{4} &= 1 \\ 
\frac{7}{4}k &= 1 \\
k &= 0.5714
\end{aligned}
$$

## Problem 2: 

(1): For $f(t)$ to be a pdf, $\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}f(t)dt = 1$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{0}^{\infty}ce^{-2t}dt &= 1 \\
c \int_{0}^{\infty}e^{-2t}dt &= 1 \\
c \int_0^{\infty} e^u -\frac{1}{2}du &= 1 \\
c \int_0^{\infty} \frac{-e^u}{2}du &= 1 \\
\frac{-c}{2} \int_0^{\infty} e^udu &= 1 \\
\bigg[-\frac{1}{2}ce^{-2t}\bigg]_{0}^{\infty} &= 1 \\
\lim_{t \rightarrow \infty} (-\frac{1}{2}ce^{-2t}) - (-\frac{1}{2}c) &= 1 \\
0 + \frac{1}{2}c &= 1 \\
c &= 2
\end{aligned}
$$
